lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: Welcome to the world of the Browser Router in React! This tool helps create navigable web apps by managing navigation and URL paths.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
First, we need to import BrowserRouter from the react-router-dom package.

Make sure to pick import, followed by BrowserRouter, and finally "react-router-dom".

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
To enable routing, we use the imported BrowserRouter component.

That's the first step to enable routing through different URL paths.

Make sure to pick <BrowserRouter>, followed by </BrowserRouter>.

lessons.title: Lesson #4 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In most cases, the BrowserRouter should be the most outer element. We render the route we want to display currently inside.

Make sure to pick <BrowserRouter>, followed by </BrowserRouter>.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Next, we'll set up routes using the Routes component from react-router-dom.

Import Routes into your project.

Make sure to pick Routes.

lessons.title: Lesson #6 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To organize routes, we add the Routes component.

Make sure to pick <Routes>, followed by </Routes>.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
The Route component defines a path and the component to render when the path matches.

Let's add another route for Mordor.

Make sure to pick Route, followed by Route.

lessons.title: Lesson #7 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The Route component defines a path and the component to render when the path matches.

Import the Route component from react-router-dom.

Make sure to pick Route.

lessons.title: Lesson #7 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finally, we render the Route component, which uses path to match URLs and element to define what to display.

Make sure to pick <Route, followed by path, and finally element.

lessons.title: Lesson #7 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can pass any component to the Route element to be rendered.

Import the Home component from "./Home" and pass it to the route.

Make sure to pick Home followed by "./Home" and then <, Home, /, >.

lessons.title: Lesson #7 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can define multiple routes. "/ is called the root path and serves as our application's starting point or default route.

Other routes can be called as we want.

Make sure to pick path= followed by "/" and then path=, "/about".

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set up routing using BrowserRouter to enable routing in your React app.

Make sure to pick <BrowserRouter>, followed by </BrowserRouter>.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the primary purpose of the BrowserRouter component?

Enables navigation between URLsStyles web pagesFetches data from an APIOptimizes React performance

Enables navigation between URLs.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a new route using the Route component to render a "Gallery" page at the "/" root path.

Make sure to pick path, followed by =, and finally "/".

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
If you want to render a component based on the URL path in a React app, which component would you use?

RouteRouterLinkNavigate

Make sure to pick Route.

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the Route component.

Make sure to pick <Route followed by path and then =, "/", element, =, {, <Main />, }, />.

lessons.title: Lesson #17
lessons.interactiveContent:
After adding a new route to your routes setup, what needs to match between the Route and the browser URL for a component to be displayed?

PathBackground ColorFont StyleNetwork Speed

Make sure to pick Path.

lessons.title: Lesson #18
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass the path to the Route component to make the Favorites component the root route.

Make sure to type "/".

lessons.title: Lesson #19
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which element attribute in the Route component specifies the component to be rendered?

elementcomponentrenderpath

Make sure to pick element.

lessons.title: Lesson #20
lessons.interactiveContent:
Define the path for the Contact component within your routes.

Make sure to pick "/contact".

lessons.title: Lesson #21
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the path attribute in the Route component define?

The URL path to matchThe name of the JavaScript fileThe type of HTTP requestThe color of the component

The URL path to match.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: Let's learn how to utilize links within a navigation bar to effortlessly switch between different pages in a React app.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's look at an example where we render the BrowserRouter component inside an App component which is rendered in the index.jsx file.

Make sure to pick BrowserRouter followed by App and then <BrowserRouter>, </BrowserRouter>, App.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
A common pattern is to create a navigation bar component and render it next to the routes.

This will lead to the navigation bar being always visible and the content of a route rendered below.

Make sure to pick NavigationBar followed by <nav> and then </nav>, <NavigationBar />.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use the Link components to allow navigation between the available routes.

Import Link from react-router-dom.

Make sure to pick Link, followed by from, and finally "react-router-dom".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The Link component needs one property called to defining the route to navigate to. A Link tag renders an anchor tag in the browser.

The text it should display should be passed as a child between an opening and a closing tag.

Make sure to pick <Link followed by to="/" and then >, Home, </Link>.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The defined routes should match the defined paths inside the Routes component.

Make sure to pick "/" followed by "/about" and then ="/", "/about".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can import the Link component in every component and use it however we want. We must ensure we pass a property to with the path.

We only need to check whether the route is specified inside the Routes component.

Make sure to pick Link followed by <Link and then to="/work", >, </Link>.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a simple navigation bar component that uses a nav for navigating to Home and About.

Make sure to pick NavigationBar followed by <nav> and then </nav>, <NavigationBar />.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the Link component do in a React Router context?

It renders an anchor tag for navigationIt creates a button element instead of an anchor tagIt replaces the whole browser windowIt sends a network request

It renders an anchor tag for navigation.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Modify the NavigationBar to include a Contact link.

Make sure to type to="/contact".

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is essential for the Link component to function correctly inside a component?

It must be wrapped in a BrowserRouterIt must be wrapped in a divIt must be inside a formIt requires a method called handleClick

It must be wrapped in a BrowserRouter.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add the link to the root route to the navigation element.

Make sure to pick <Link followed by to="/"> and then Home, </Link>.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
What element does the <Link> component render in a React application?

a elementbutton elementdiv elementspan element

a element.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's explore manually navigating between different pages, for example, when we need to do calculations first or wait before navigating.

We'll learn about the useNavigate and useLocation hooks.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
To navigate programmatically, we need to import the useNavigate hook from the react-router-dom package.

Make sure to pick import followed by { and then useNavigate, }, from, "react-router-dom".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use useNavigate to get the navigate function, which lets us programmatically change the user's route.

Create the variable navigate and save the navigation function for future use.

Make sure to pick const, followed by navigate, and finally useNavigate().

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Once we have access to navigate, we can pass it a path as the argument and manually move between routes.

Call navigate with the argument "/about" to navigate to the specified route.

Make sure to pick navigate, followed by "/about".

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Using navigate instead of the Link component allows us to fully control the navigation process.

Call goToAboutPage on button click.

Make sure to pick goToAboutPage, followed by onClick, and finally goToAboutPage.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now, let's learn how to check the current location in our app using useLocation. It's another useful hook from react-router-dom.

Make sure to pick useLocation followed by "react-router-dom" and then const, location, useLocation().

lessons.title: Lesson #8 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access the current path from the location object that the hook returned, we use location.pathname.

Make sure to pick location, followed by ., and finally pathname.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Navigate to the "/tea" route.

Make sure to pick navigate followed by ( and then "/tea", ).

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the useNavigate hook do in React Router?

Allows programmatic navigation between routesRenders a button componentFetches data from an APIHandles form submissions

Allows programmatic navigation between routes.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set up the code to allow using navigate("/burger") on button click.

Make sure to pick const followed by navigate and then =, useNavigate(), ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which React Router hook allows you to access the current location of the app?

useLocationuseRouteMatchuseNavigateuseHistory

Make sure to pick useLocation.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Make use of the useLocation hook to display the current path.

Make sure to pick { followed by location and then ., pathname, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's true about the useLocation hook?

It can be used to retrieve the current pathIt can be used to update state variablesIt can be used to call a function after renderingWe should not use it at all

It can be used to retrieve the current path.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Navigate to the "/dog" route when the button is clicked.

Make sure to pick (), followed by =>, and finally navigate("/dog").
